name: Chain Rule for Derivatives
explanation: The chain rule finds the derivative of composite functions (functions within functions). If y = f(g(x)), then dy/dx = f'(g(x)) · g'(x). In words: derivative of the outer function (evaluated at the inner function) times the derivative of the inner function. This is essential for differentiating functions like sin(x²) or (x² + 1)³.

steps: Outer function: u³, Inner function: u = x² + 1

proof: Let y = f(u) and u = g(x), so y = f(g(x)). By definition: dy/dx = lim(h→0) [f(g(x+h)) - f(g(x))]/h. Multiply by [g(x+h) - g(x)]/[g(x+h) - g(x)]: = lim(h→0) {[f(g(x+h)) - f(g(x))]/[g(x+h) - g(x)]} × {[g(x+h) - g(x)]/h}. As h→0, g(x+h) - g(x) → 0, so first factor → f'(g(x)) = f'(u), second factor → g'(x). Therefore: dy/dx = f'(u) × g'(x) = f'(g(x)) × g'(x).
